==Economy== ===Salt trade=== [[File:Bilma-Salzkarawane1.jpg|thumb|Azalai salt caravan, mid-December 1985.]] The wealth and very existence of Timbuktu depended on its position as the southern terminus of an important trans-Saharan trade route; nowadays, the only goods that are routinely transported across the desert are slabs of rock salt brought from the [[Taoudenni]] mining centre in the central Sahara {{convert|664|km|abbr=on}} north of Timbuktu. Until the second half of the 20th century most of the slabs were transported by large salt caravans or [[azalai]], one leaving Timbuktu in early November and the other in late March.{{sfn|Miner|1953|p=68 n27}}
The caravans of several thousand camels took three weeks each way, transporting food to the miners and returning with each camel loaded with four or five {{convert|30|kg|0|abbr=on}} slabs of salt. The salt transport was largely controlled by the desert nomads of the Arabic-speaking Berabich (or Barabish) tribe.<ref>{{citation |last=Meunier |first=D. |year=1980 |title=Le commerce du sel de Taoudeni |journal=Journal des Africanistes |volume=50 |issue=2 |pages=133–144 |url=http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/jafr_0399-0346_1980_num_50_2_2010 |doi=10.3406/jafr.1980.2010 |language=French }}</ref> Although there are no roads, the slabs of salt are now usually transported from Taoudenni by truck.<ref>{{citation |last=Harding |first=Andrew |date=3 December 2009 |title=Timbuktu's ancient salt caravans under threat |publisher=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8393442.stm |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref> From Timbuktu the salt is transported by boat to other towns in Mali.
Between the 12th and 14th centuries, Timbuktu's population grew immensely due to an influx of [[Tuareg people|Tuaregs]], [[Fula people|Fulanis]], and [[Songhai people|Songhais]] seeking trade, security, or to study. By 1300, the population increased to 10,000 and kept increasing until it reached about 50,000 in the 1500s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Maynes |first1=Mary Jo |last2=Waltner |first2=Ann |title=The Family: A World History |date=2012 |publisher=Oxford University Press, Inc |location=New York |isbn=9780195338140 |page=45}}</ref>
===Agriculture=== There is insufficient rainfall in the Timbuktu region for purely rain-fed agriculture and crops are therefore irrigated using water from the River Niger. The main agricultural crop is rice. African floating rice (''[[Oryza glaberrima]]'') has traditionally been grown in regions near the river that are inundated during the annual flood. Seed is sown at the beginning of the rainy season (June–July) so that when the flood water arrives plants are already {{convert|30|to|40|cm|0|abbr=on}} in height.<ref>{{citation |last1=Thom |first1=Derrick J. |last2=Wells |first2=John C. |year=1987 |title=Farming Systems in the Niger Inland Delta, Mali |journal=Geographical Review |volume=77 |issue=3 |pages=328–342 |jstor=214124 |doi=10.2307/214124}}</ref>
The plants grow up to {{convert|3|m|ft|spell=in|abbr=off}} in height as the water level rises. The rice is harvested by canoe in December. The procedure is very precarious and the yields are low but the method has the advantage that little capital investment is required. A successful crop depends critically on the amount and timing of the rain in the wet season and the height of the flood. To a limited extent the arrival of the flood water can be controlled by the construction of small mud dikes that become submerged as the water rises.
Although floating rice is still cultivated in the [[Timbuktu Cercle]], most of the rice is now grown in three relatively large irrigated areas that lie to the south of the town: Daye (392 ha), Koriomé (550 ha) and Hamadja (623 ha).<ref name="schema">{{citation | title=Schéma Directeur d'Urbanisme de la Ville de Tombouctou et Environs | year=2006 | url=http://www.logements.gouv.ml/documentation/schema_directeur_tombouctou.pdf | publisher=Ministère de l'Habitat et de l'Urbanisme, République du Mali | place=Bamako, Mali | language=French | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428074053/http://www.logements.gouv.ml/documentation/schema_directeur_tombouctou.pdf | archivedate=28 April 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Water is pumped from the river using ten large [[Archimedes' screw]]s which were first installed in the 1990s. The irrigated areas are run as [[cooperative]]s with approximately 2,100 families cultivating small plots.<ref name="USAIDcircle">{{citation | title=Synthèse des Plan de Securité Alimentaire des Communes du Circle de Tombouctou 2006–2010 | publisher=Commissariat à la Sécurité Alimentaire, République du Mali, USAID-Mali | year=2006 | url=http://www.aec.msu.edu/fs2/mali_fd_strtgy/plans/tombouctou/tombouctou/synthese_cercle_tombouctou.pdf | language=French | access-date=2 May 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906163402/http://www.aec.msu.edu/fs2/mali_fd_strtgy/plans/tombouctou/tombouctou/synthese_cercle_tombouctou.pdf | archive-date=6 September 2011 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Nearly all the rice produced is consumed by the families themselves. The yields are still relatively low and the farmers are being encouraged to change their agricultural practices.<ref name="styger">{{citation |last=Styger |first=Erika |year=2010 |title=Introducing the System of Rice Intensification (SRI) to irrigated systems in Gao, Mopti, Timbuktu and to rainfed systems in Sikasso |publisher=USAID, Initiatives Intégrées pour la Croissance Économique au Mali, Abt Associates |place=Bamako, Mali |url=http://sri.ciifad.cornell.edu/countries/mali/Mali_IICEMStyger2009_2010.pdf }}</ref>
===Tourism=== Most tourists visit Timbuktu between November and February when the air temperature is lower. In the 1980s, accommodation for the small number of tourists was provided by two small hotels: Hotel Bouctou and Hotel Azalaï.<ref name="desherence">{{citation |last=Sayah |first=Moulaye |title=Tombouctou : le tourisme en desherence |url=http://www.essor.ml/regions/article/tombouctou-le-tourisme-en |publisher=L'Essor |date=3 October 2011 |accessdate=28 November 2011 |language=French }}</ref> Over the following decades the tourist numbers increased so that by 2006 there were seven small hotels and guest houses.<ref name="schema" /> The town benefited by the revenue from the CFA 5000 tourist tax,<ref name="schema" /> by the sale of handicrafts and by the employment for the guides.
====Attacks==== Starting in 2008 the [[Al-Qaeda Organization in the Islamic Maghreb]] began kidnapping groups of tourists in the Sahel region.<ref>{{citation | title=Travelling and living abroad: Sahel | publisher=United Kingdom Foreign and Commonwealth Office | url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/your-trip/sahel | accessdate=1 January 2012 }}</ref> In January 2009, four tourists were kidnapped near the Mali–Niger border after attending a cultural festival at [[Anderamboukané]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUKLM333916 | title= Mali says Tuareg rebels abduct group of tourists | date= 22 January 2009 | publisher=Reuters | accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> One of these tourists was subsequently murdered.<ref>{{citation | title=Al-Qaeda 'kills British hostage' | date=3 June 2009 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8080447.stm | publisher=BBC News | accessdate=1 January 2012 }}</ref> As a result of this and various other incidents a number of states including France,<ref>{{citation | title=Mali: Securite | url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays/mali-12287/ | publisher=Ministère des affaires étrangères et européennes | accessdate=28 November 2011 | language=French }}</ref> Britain<ref>{{citation | publisher=United Kingdom Foreign and Commonwealth Office | title=Mali travel advice | url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/sub-saharan-africa/mali | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004045843/http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/sub-saharan-africa/mali | dead-url=yes | archive-date=4 October 2009 | accessdate=28 November 2011 }}</ref> and the US,<ref>{{citation | title=Travel Warning US Department of State, Bureau of Consular Affairs: Mali | url=https://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/tw/tw_5360.html | publisher=US Department of State | date=4 October 2011 | accessdate=28 November 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111126112805/http://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/tw/tw_5360.html | archive-date=26 November 2011 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> began advising their citizens to avoid travelling far from Bamako. The number of tourists visiting Timbuktu dropped precipitously from around 6000 in 2009 to only 492 in the first four months of 2011.<ref name="desherence" />
Because of the security concerns, the Malian government moved the 2010 [[Festival au Désert|Festival in the Desert]] from [[Essakane]] to the outskirts of Timbuktu.<ref>{{citation |last=Togola |first=Diakaridia |title=Festival sur le désert : Essakane a vibré au rythme de la 10ème édition |url=http://www.maliweb.net/category.php?NID=55243 |language=French |publisher=Le Quotidien de Bamako |date=11 January 2010 |accessdate=25 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415085152/http://www.maliweb.net/category.php?NID=55243 |archivedate=15 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{citation | title=Tombouctou: Le Festival du Désert aura bien lieu | publisher=Primature: Portail Officiel du Gouvernement Mali | url=http://www.primature.gov.ml/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5562:tombouctou-le-festival-du-desert-aura-bien-lieu&catid=12 | date=28 October 2010 | accessdate=25 December 2011 | language=French | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924082337/http://www.primature.gov.ml/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5562%3Atombouctou-le-festival-du-desert-aura-bien-lieu&catid=12 | archivedate=24 September 2015 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> In November 2011, gunmen attacked tourists staying at a hotel in Timbuktu, killing one of them and kidnapping three others.<ref>{{cite news | title= Mali kidnapping: One dead and three seized in Timbuktu | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15895908 | date=25 November 2011 | publisher= BBC News | accessdate=28 November 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{citation |last=Sayad |first=Moulaye |title=Tombouctou : Sous le Choc |date=28 November 2011 |publisher=L'Essor |url= http://www.essor.ml/regions/article/tombouctou-sous-le-choc |language=French |accessdate=1 January 2012 }}</ref> This was the first terrorist incident in Timbuktu itself.
On 1 April 2012, one day after the capture of [[Gao]], Timbuktu was captured from the Malian military by the [[2012 Tuareg rebellion|Tuareg rebels]] of the [[National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad|MNLA]] and [[Ansar Dine]].<ref>{{citation |last=Callimachi |first=Rukmini |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/nation-world/mali-coup-leader-reinstates-1403759.html |title=Mali coup leader reinstates old constitution |date=1 April 2012 |work=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=31 March 2012}}</ref> Five days later, the MNLA declared the region independent of Mali as the nation of [[Azawad]].<ref name="english.alarabiya.net">{{citation|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/04/06/205763.html|agency=Al Arabiya|title=Tuareg rebels declare the independence of Azawad, north of Mali|date=6 April 2012|accessdate=6 April 2012}}</ref> The declared political entity was not recognized by any regional nations or the international community and it collapsed three months later on 12 July.<ref>{{citation |last=Moseley |first=Walter G. |title=Azawad: the latest African Border Dilemma |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2012/04/20124149184982408.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=18 April 2012}}</ref>
On 28 January 2013, French and Malian government troops began retaking Timbuktu from the Islamist rebels.<ref>{{citation |last=Diarra |first=Adam |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/01/28/us-mali-rebels-idUSBRE90O0C720130128 |title=French seal off Mali's Timbuktu, rebels torch library |publisher=Reuters |date=28 January 2013}}</ref> The force of 1,000 French troops with 200 Malian soldiers retook Timbuktu without a fight. The Islamist groups had already fled north a few days earlier, having set fire to the [[Ahmed Baba Institute]], which housed many important manuscripts. The building housing the Ahmed Baba Institute was funded by South Africa, and held 30,000 manuscripts. BBC World Service radio news reported on 29 January 2013 that approximately 28,000 of the manuscripts in the Institute had been removed to safety from the premises before the attack by the Islamist groups, and that the whereabouts of about 2,000 manuscripts remained unknown.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shamil |first=Jeppie |title=Timbuktu Manuscripts Project |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21242689 |accessdate=29 January 2013 |publisher=BBC News |date=29 January 2013}} Also broadcast BBC World Service news on 29 January 2013.</ref> It was intended to be a resource for Islamic research.<ref>{{cite web |author=Staff |url=http://africajournalismtheworld.com/tag/timbuktu-library-burned/ |title=Mali – Islamists Rebels Burn Manuscript Library as They Leave Timbuktu |publisher=Reuters (via Africa – News and Analysis) |date=28 January 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2013}}</ref>
On 30 March 2013, jihadist rebels [[2nd Battle of Timbuktu|infiltrated]] into Timbuktu nine days before a [[Battle of Timbuktu|suicide bombing]] on a Malian army checkpoint at the international airport killing a soldier. Fighting lasted until 1 April, when French warplanes helped Malian ground forces chase the remaining rebels out of the city center.
==Early accounts== Tales of Timbuktu's fabulous wealth helped prompt European exploration of the west coast of Africa. Among the most famous descriptions of Timbuktu are those of [[Leo Africanus]] and Shabeni.
===Leo Africanus===
Perhaps most famous among the accounts written about Timbuktu is that by [[Leo Africanus]]. Born El Hasan ben Muhammed el- Wazzan-ez-Zayyati in [[Granada]] in 1485, his family was among the thousands of Muslims expelled by King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella after their [[Granada War|reconquest of Spain]] in 1492. They settled in [[Morocco]], where he studied in [[Fes]] and accompanied his uncle on diplomatic missions throughout North Africa. During these travels, he visited Timbuktu. As a young man he was captured by pirates and presented as an exceptionally learned slave to [[Pope Leo X]], who freed him, [[baptism|baptized]] him under the name "Johannis Leo de Medici", and commissioned him to write, in Italian, a detailed survey of Africa. His accounts provided most of what Europeans [[European exploration of Africa|knew about the continent]] for the next several centuries.{{sfn|Leo Africanus|1896}} Describing Timbuktu when the [[Songhai Empire]] was at its height, the English edition of his book includes the description: {{Quote|quote = The rich king of Tombuto hath many plates and sceptres of gold, some whereof weigh 1300 pounds. ... He hath always 3000 horsemen ... (and) a great store of doctors, judges, priests, and other learned men, that are bountifully maintained at the king's cost and charges. |source = [[Leo Africanus]], ''[[Description of Africa (1550 book)|Descrittione dell' Africa]]''{{sfn|Leo Africanus|1896|p=[https://archive.org/stream/historyanddescr02porygoog#page/n140/mode/1up 824 Vol. 3]}} |width = 30% |align = right }}
According to Leo Africanus, there were abundant supplies of locally produced corn, cattle, milk and butter, though there were neither gardens nor orchards surrounding the city.<ref name=brians>{{cite book |last=Brians |first=Paul |title=Reading About the World |publisher=Harcourt Brace College Publishing |year=1998 |location=Fort Worth, TX, USA |pages=vol. II |url=http://www.wsu.edu:8080/~wldciv/world_civ_reader/world_civ_reader_2/leo_africanus.html }}</ref> In another passage dedicated to describing the wealth of both the environment and the king, Africanus touches upon the rarity of one of Timbuktu's trade commodities: salt. {{Quote|quote = The inhabitants are very rich, especially the strangers who have settled in the country [..] But salt is in very short supply because it is carried here from [[Tegaza]], some {{convert|500|mi|0|abbr=out}} from Timbuktu. I happened to be in this city at a time when a load of salt sold for eighty [[ducats]]. The king has a rich treasure of coins and [[ingot|gold ingots]]. |source = [[Leo Africanus]], ''[[Description of Africa (1550 book)|Descrittione dell' Africa]]'' in Paul Brians' ''Reading About the World'', Volume 2<ref name=brians/>|width = 30% |align = right}}
These descriptions and passages alike caught the attention of European explorers. Africanus, though, also described the more mundane aspects of the city, such as the "cottages built of [[chalk]], and covered with [[thatch]]" – although these went largely unheeded.{{sfn|Insoll|2004}}
===Shabeni=== {{Quote box |quote = The natives of the town of Timbuctoo may be computed at 40,000, exclusive of slaves and foreigners ... The natives are all blacks: almost every stranger marries a female of the town, who are so beautiful that travellers often fall in love with them at first sight.|source = – Shabeni in {{Ill|James Grey Jackson|fr|lt=James Grey Jackson's}} ''An Account of Timbuctoo and Hausa'', 1820{{sfn|Jackson|1820|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=BAtFAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q&f=false 10]}} |width = 30% |align = right }} Roughly 250 years after Leo Africanus' visit to Timbuktu, the city had seen many rulers. The end of the 18th century saw the grip of the Moroccan rulers on the city wane, resulting in a period of unstable government by quickly changing tribes. During the rule of one of those tribes, the [[Hausa people|Hausa]], a 14-year-old child named Shabeni (or Shabeeny) from [[Tetuan]] on the north coast of Morocco accompanied his father on a visit to Timbuktu.{{sfn|Jackson|1820}}
Shabeni stayed in Timbuktu for three years before moving to a major city called [[Housa]]<ref>[http://www.jstor.org/stable/221615 A paper] from 1995 says this was "apparently one of the [[Maraka]] towns". [https://books.google.fr/books?id=x_5ZDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA154&lpg=PA154&dq=housa+%22niger+River%22+-house&source=bl&ots=gGqQVINS4J&sig=kmYvmWvD_gVAjhb6otz-ER7sRUI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiN6PPCjNvcAhUyzoUKHZXUB6YQ6AEwEHoECDsQAQ#v=onepage&q=housa%20%22niger%20River%22%20-house&f=false A book] of letters to [[Thomas Jefferson]] mentions in connexion to a letter of 1798 that explorer [[Mungo Park (explorer)|Mungo Park]] had tried unsuccessfully to find Housa and Timbuktu (1795-7). In a later expedition he went near Timbuktu while descending the [[Niger River]]. After being attacked many times by Africans he drowned in the river.</ref> several days journey to the southeast. Two years later, he returned to Timbuktu to live there for another seven years – one of a population that was even centuries after its peak and excluding slaves, double the size of the 21st-century town.
By the time Shabeni was 27, he was an established merchant in his hometown of Tetuan. He made a two-year pilgrimage to [[Mecca]] and thus became a [[hajji]], Asseed El Hage Abd Salam Shabeeny. Returning from a trading voyage to [[History of Hamburg|Hamburg]], he was captured by a ship manned by Englishmen but sailing under a Russian flag, whose captain claimed that his Imperial mistress ([[Catherine the Great]]) was "at war with all Muselmen" (see [[Russo-Turkish War (1787–1792)]]). He and the ship he had been sailing in were brought to [[Ostend]] in Belgium in December 1789 but the British consul managed to get him and the ship released. He set off again in the same ship, but the captain, who claimed to be afraid of his ship being captured again, set him ashore in [[Dover]]. In England his story was recorded. Shabeeni gave an indication of the size of the city in the second half of the 18th century. In an earlier passage, he described an environment that was characterized by forest, as opposed to nowadays' arid surroundings.
==Arts and culture== [[File:Timbuktu-139086.jpg|thumb|Reconstruction of the Ben Essayouti Library, Timbuktu]]
===Cultural events=== The most well-known cultural event is the [[Festival au Désert]].<ref name=reiser/> When the Tuareg rebellion ended in 1996 under the Konaré administration, 3,000 weapons were burned in a ceremony dubbed the Flame of Peace on 29 March 2007 – to commemorate the ceremony, a monument was built.{{sfn|Jeppie|2008}} The [[Festival au Désert]], to celebrate the [[peace treaty]], is held near the city in January.<ref name=reiser>{{Cite book |last=Reiser |first=Melissa Diane |title=Festival au Desert, Essakane, Mali: a postcolonial, postwar Tuareg experiment |publisher=University of Wisconsin – Madison |year=2007 |location=Madison |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=47FfAAAAMAAJ }}</ref>
===World Heritage Site=== During its twelfth session, in December 1988, the [[World Heritage Committee]] (WHC) selected parts of Timbuktu's historic centre for inscription on its [[List of World Heritage Sites in Africa|World Heritage list]].<ref name=whsselection>{{Citation | contribution = Report of the World Heritage Committee Twelfth Session | contribution-url = http://whc.unesco.org/archive/repcom88.htm#119 |title=Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage | series = | year = 1988 | place = Brasilia | publisher=UNESCO | url = http://whc.unesco.org/archive/repcom88.htm }}</ref> The selection was based on three [[World Heritage Site#Cultural criteria|criteria]]:<ref name=ICOMOS/> *Criterion II: Timbuktu's holy places were vital to early [[Islamization]] in Africa. *Criterion IV: Timbuktu's mosques show a cultural and scholarly [[Golden Age]] during the [[Songhay Empire]]. *Criterion V: The construction of the mosques, still mostly original, shows the use of traditional building techniques.
An earlier nomination in 1979 failed the following year as it lacked proper demarcation:<ref name=ICOMOS>{{cite web |last=[[ICOMOS]] |title=Advisory Body Evaluation of Timbuktu Nomination |publisher=UNESCO |date=14 May 1979 |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/advisory_body_evaluation/119.pdf |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref> the Malian government included the town of Timbuktu as a whole in the wish for inclusion.<ref name=orignom>{{cite web |last=Mali Government |title=Nomination No. 119 |work=Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage |publisher=UNESCO |date=14 May 1979 |url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0003/000377/037756eb.pdf |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref> Close to a decade later, three mosques and 16 [[mausoleum]]s or cemeteries were selected from the Old Town for [[World Heritage Site|World Heritage status]]: with this conclusion came the call for protection of the buildings' conditions, an exclusion of new construction works near the sites and measures against the [[desertification|encroaching sand]].
Shortly afterwards, the monuments were placed on the [[List of World Heritage in Danger]] by the [[Politics of Mali|Malian government]], as by the selection committee at the time of nomination.<ref name=whsselection/> The first period on the Danger List lasted from 1990 until 2005, when a range of measures including restoration work and the compilation of an inventory warranted "its removal from the Danger List".<ref>{{cite web |last=Amelan |first=Roni |title=Three Sites Withdrawn from UNESCO's List of World Heritage in Danger |work=World Heritage Convention News & Events |publisher=UNESCO |date=13 July 2005 |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/133/ |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref> In 2008 the WHC placed the protected area under increased scrutiny dubbed "reinforced monitoring", a measure made possible in 2007, as the impact of planned construction work was unclear. Special attention was given to the build of a [[cultural centre]].<ref>{{cite web | title = WHC Requests Close Surveillance of Bordeaux, Machu Picchu, Timbuktu and Samarkand | work=World Heritage Convention News & Events | publisher=UNESCO | date = 10 July 2008 | url = http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/454 | accessdate =22 February 2011}}</ref>
During a session in June 2009, [[UNESCO]] decided to cease its increased monitoring program as it felt sufficient progress had been made to address the initial concerns.<ref>{{Citation | title = Decision 33COM 7B.45 – Timbuktu (Mali) | series = Final Decisions of the 33rd Session of the WHC | place = Seville | year = 2009 | url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/decisions/1837}}</ref> Following the takeover of Timbuktu by MNLA and the Islamist group Ansar Dine, it was returned to the List of World Heritage in Danger in 2012.<ref name=TimbuktuDamageJune>{{cite news | title=Timbuktu shrines damaged by Mali Ansar Dine Islamists | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18657463 | publisher=BBC News | date=30 June 2012 | accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref>
====Attacks by Muslim fundamentalists==== {{Further|Islamist destruction of Timbuktu heritage sites}} In May 2012, Ansar Dine destroyed a shrine in the city<ref name=TimbuktuDamageMay>{{cite news | title=Mali Islamist militants 'destroy' Timbuktu saint's tomb | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17973545 | publisher=BBC News | date=6 May 2012 | accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> and in June 2012, in the aftermath of the [[Battle of Gao and Timbuktu]], other shrines, including the mausoleum of [[Sidi Mahmoud Ben Amar|Sidi Mahmoud]], were destroyed when attacked with shovels and pickaxes by members of the same group.<ref name=TimbuktuDamageJune/> An Ansar Dine spokesman said that ''all'' shrines in the city, including the 13 remaining World Heritage sites, would be destroyed because they consider them to be examples of [[idolatry]], a [[Shirk (Islam)|sin in Islam]].<ref name=TimbuktuDamageJune/><ref>Al Jazeera (1 June 2012). ''[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/06/2012630101748795606.html Ansar Dine fighters destroy Timbuktu shrines.]'' Retrieved 1 July 2012</ref> These acts have been described as crimes against humanity and war crimes.<ref name=TimbuktuEndTimes>Guled Yusuf and Lucas Bento, ''The New York Times'' (31 July 2012). ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/01/opinion/the-end-times-for-timbuktu.html The 'End Times' for Timbuktu?]'' Retrieved 31 July 2012</ref> After the destruction of the tombs, UNESCO created a special fund to safeguard Mali's World Heritage Sites, vowing to carry out reconstruction and rehabilitation projects once the security situation allows.<ref>{{cite web |author=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/913 |title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre - Creation of a Special Fund for the Safeguarding of Mali’s World Heritage sites |publisher=Whc.unesco.org |accessdate=2014-05-16}}</ref>
==Education== {{quote box |width=20% |align=left |border = 1px |quote= If the University of Sankore ... had survived the ravages of foreign invasions, the academic and cultural history of Africa might have been different from what it is today. |source= – [[Kwame Nkrumah]] at the [[University of Ghana]] inauguration, 1961{{sfn|Jeppie|2008}} }}
===Centre of learning=== [[File:Timbuktu-manuscripts-astronomy-mathematics.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[Timbuktu Manuscripts]] showing both [[mathematics]] and a heritage of [[astronomy in medieval Islam]].]] Timbuktu was a world centre of Islamic learning from the 13th to the 17th century, especially under the Mali Empire and Askia Mohammad I's rule. The Malian government and NGOs have been working to catalog and restore the remnants of this scholarly legacy: Timbuktu's manuscripts.<ref name=Huddleston>{{Cite journal |last=Huddleston |first=Alexandra |title=Divine Learning: The Traditional Islamic Scholarship of Timbuktu |journal=Fourth Genre: Explorations in Non-Fiction |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages=129–135 |date=1 September 2009 |issn=1522-3868 |doi=10.1353/fge.0.0080}}</ref>
Timbuktu's rapid economic growth in the 13th and 14th centuries drew many scholars from nearby [[Walata]] (today in [[Mauretania]]),{{sfn|Cleaveland|2008}} leading up to the city's golden age in the 15th and 16th centuries that proved fertile ground for scholarship of religions, arts and sciences. To the people of Timbuktu, literacy and books were symbols of wealth, power, and blessings and the acquisition of books became a primary concern for scholars.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Singleton|first1=Brent D.|title=African Bibliophiles: Books and Libraries in Medieval Timbuktu|journal=Libraries & Culture|date=2004|volume=39|issue=1|pages=1–12|jstor=25549150|doi=10.1353/lac.2004.0019}}</ref> An active trade in books between Timbuktu and other parts of the [[Muslim history|Islamic world]] and emperor [[Askia Mohammed]]'s strong support led to the writing of thousands of [[manuscript]]s.<ref>{{Cite book |title=African Cultural Astronomy |last=Medupe |first=Rodney Thebe |last2=Warner |first2=Brian |last3=Jeppie |first3=Shamil |last4=Sanogo |first4=Salikou |last5=Maiga |first5=Mohammed |last6=Maiga |first6=Ahmed |last7=Dembele |first7=Mamadou |last8=Diakite |first8=Drissa |last9=Tembely |first9=Laya |year=2008 |isbn=9781402066399 |editor-last=Holbrook |editor-first=Jarita |series=Astrophysics and Space Science Proceedings |at=p. 179 |chapter=The Timbuktu Astronomy Project |doi=10.1007/978-1-4020-6639-9_13 |editor-last2=Medupe |editor-first2=R. Thebe |editor-last3=Urama |editor-first3=Johnson O. |last10=Kanoute |first10=Mamadou |last11=Traore |first11=Sibiri |last12=Sodio |first12=Bernard |last13=Hawkes |first13=Sharron}}</ref>
Knowledge was gathered in a manner similar to the early, informal [[Medieval university|European Medieval university]] model.{{sfn|Cleaveland|2008}} Lecturing was presented through a range of informal institutions called [[madrasahs]].<ref name="Makdisi Scholasticism">{{citation |last=Makdisi |first=George |title=Scholasticism and Humanism in Classical Islam and the Christian West |journal=Journal of the American Oriental Society |volume=109 |issue=2 |date=April–June 1989 |pages=175–182 [176] |doi=10.2307/604423 |jstor=604423 }}</ref> Nowadays known as the [[University of Timbuktu]], three ''madrasahs'' facilitated 25,000 students: [[Djinguereber Mosque|Djinguereber]], [[Sidi Yahya Mosque|Sidi Yahya]] and [[Sankore Madrasah|Sankore]].<ref>[http://www.timbuktufoundation.org/university.html University of Timbuktu, Mali] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120924080621/http://www.timbuktufoundation.org/university.html |date=24 September 2012 }} – Timbuktu Educational Foundation</ref>
These institutions were explicitly religious, as opposed to the more secular curricula of modern European universities and more similar to the medieval Europe model. However, where universities in the European sense started as associations of students and teachers, West-African education was [[patronage|patronized]] by families or lineages, with the Aqit and Bunu al-Qadi al-Hajj families being two of the most prominent in Timbuktu – these families also facilitated students is set-aside rooms in their housings.{{sfn|Hunwick|2003|pp=lvii}} Although the basis of [[Sharia|Islamic law]] and its teaching were brought to Timbuktu from North Africa with the spread of Islam, Western African scholarship developed: [[Ahmad Baba al Massufi]] is regarded as the city's greatest scholar.<ref name="baba_the_greatest">{{cite news |first=Lydia |last=Polgreen |title=Timbuktu Hopes Ancient Texts Spark a Revival |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/07/world/africa/07mali.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=7 August 2007 |accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref>
Timbuktu served in this process as a distribution centre of scholars and scholarship. Its reliance on trade meant intensive movement of scholars between the city and its extensive network of trade partners. In 1468–1469 though, many scholars left for Walata when [[Sunni Ali]]'s Songhay Empire absorbed Timbuktu and again in 1591 with the Moroccan occupation.{{sfn|Cleaveland|2008}}
This system of education survived until the late 19th century, while the 18th century saw the institution of itinerant Quranic school as a form of universal education, where scholars would travel throughout the region with their students, begging for food part of the day.<ref name=Huddleston/> Islamic education came under pressure after the French occupation, droughts in the 70s and 80s and by [[Tuareg Rebellion (1990–1995)|Mali's civil war]] in the early 90s.<ref name=Huddleston/>
===Manuscripts and libraries=== {{Main|Timbuktu Manuscripts}} [[File:kuntamarabut.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[Moorish]] [[marabout]] of the [[Kunta family|Kuntua tribe]], an ethnic [[Kounta]] clan, from which the Al Kounti manuscript collection derives its name. Dated 1898.]] Hundreds of thousands of manuscripts were collected in Timbuktu over the course of centuries: some were written in the town itself, others – including exclusive copies of the [[Qur'an]] for wealthy families – imported through the lively booktrade.
Hidden in cellars or buried, hid between the mosque's mud walls and safeguarded by their patrons, many of these manuscripts survived the city's decline. They now form the collection of several libraries in Timbuktu, holding up to 700,000 manuscripts:<ref name=ng>{{cite web |last=Rainier |first=Chris |title=Reclaiming the Ancient Manuscripts of Timbuktu |work=National Geographic News |date=27 May 2003 |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/05/0522_030527_timbuktu.html |accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref> In late January 2013 it was reported that rebel forces destroyed many of the manuscripts before leaving the city.<ref>{{citation |last=Harding |first=Luke |date=28 January 2013 |title=Timbuktu mayor: Mali rebels torched library of historic manuscripts |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/28/mali-timbuktu-library-ancient-manuscripts |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=27 February 2013 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{citation |last=Diarra |first=Adama |date=28 January 2013 |title=French, Malians retake Timbuktu, rebels torch library |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/01/28/uk-mali-rebels-idUKBRE90P0A120130128 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=27 February 2013}}</ref> However, there was no malicious destruction of any library or collection as most of the manuscripts were safely hidden away.<ref>{{citation | title=Timbuktu update | date= 30 January 2013| url=http://www.tombouctoumanuscripts.org/blog/entry/timbuktu_update/| publisher=Tombouctou Manuscripts Project, University of Cape Town | accessdate=27 February 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{citation |last=Zanganeh |first=Lila Azam |date=29 January 2013 |title=Has the great library of Timbuktu been lost? |url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2013/01/the-libraries-of-timbuktu.html |publisher=The New Yorker |accessdate=27 February 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{ citation | title=Precious history in Timbuktu library saved from fire | url=http://www.thehistoryblog.com/archives/23148 | publisher=The History Blog | accessdate=27 February 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{citation |last=Hinshaw |first=Drew |date=1 February 2013 |title=Historic Timbuktu Texts Saved From Burning |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323926104578276003922396218 |publisher=''The Wall Street Journal'' |accessdate=27 February 2013}}</ref> One librarian in particular, Abdel Kader Haidara, organized to have 350,000 medieval manuscripts smuggled out of Timbuktu for safekeeping.<ref>https://www.npr.org/2016/04/23/475420855/timbuktus-badass-librarians-checking-out-books-under-al-qaidas-nose</ref><ref>Hammer, J. (2016) "The Bad-Ass Librarians of Timbuktu." Simon and Schuster.</ref>
*[[Ahmed Baba Institute]] *Mamma Haidara Library *Fondo Kati *[[Mohammed Bagayogo|Al-Wangari]] Library *Mohamed Tahar Library *Maigala Library *Boularaf Collection *[[Ahmad al-Bakkai al-Kunti|Al Kounti]] Collections
[[File:Timbuktu-139085.jpg|thumb|Manuscripts of the Ahmed Baba Centre]] These libraries are the largest among up to 60 private or public libraries that are estimated to exist in Timbuktu today, although some comprise little more than a row of books on a shelf or a bookchest.<ref>{{Citation |last=Grant |first=Simon |title=Beyond the Saharan Fringe |work=The Guardian |date=8 February 2007 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2007/feb/08/beyondthesaharanfringe |accessdate=19 July 2010 |location=London}}</ref> Under these circumstances, the manuscripts are vulnerable to damage and theft, as well as long term climate damage, despite Timbuktu's arid climate. Two [[Timbuktu Manuscripts Project]]s funded by independent universities have aimed to preserve them.
During the occupation by Islamic extremists the citizens of the city embarked on a drive to save the “best written accounts of African History.” Interviewed by the Times the local residents claimed to have safeguarded the three hundred thousand manuscripts for generations. Many of these documents are still in the safe keeping of the local residents who are reluctant to give them overs to the government-run Ahmed Baba Institute housed in a modern digitalization building built by the South African government in 2009. The institute houses only 10% of the manuscripts<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://world.time.com/2013/02/04/timbuktus-ancient-libraries-saved-by-locals-endangered-by-a-government/|title=Timbuktu’s Ancient Libraries: Saved by Locals, Endangered by a Government|last=Walt|first=Vivienne|work=Time|access-date=2018-04-23|language=en-US|issn=0040-781X}}</ref> It was later confirmed by Jean-Michel Djian to the New Yorker that "the great majority of the manuscripts, about fifty thousand, are actually housed in the thirty-two family libraries of the 'City of 333 Saints{{'"}}. He added, "Those are to this day protected." He also added that due to the massive efforts of one individual two hundred thousand other manuscripts were successfully transported to safety<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/has-the-great-library-of-timbuktu-been-lost|title=Has the Great Library of Timbuktu Been Lost?|last=Zanganeh|first=Lila Azam|date=2013-01-29|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-04-23|language=en|issn=0028-792X}}</ref>
==Language== Although French is Mali's [[official language]], today the large majority of Timbuktu's inhabitants speaks [[Koyra Chiini language|Koyra Chiini]], a [[Songhay language]] that also functions as the [[lingua franca]]. Before the 1990–1994 [[Tuareg Rebellion (1990-1995)|Tuareg rebellion]], both [[Hassaniya]] Arabic and [[Tuareg languages|Tamashek]] were represented by 10% each to an 80% dominance of the Koyra Chiini language. With Tamashek spoken by both [[Ikelan]] and ethnic Tuaregs, its use declined with the expulsion of many Tuaregs following the rebellion, increasing the dominance of Koyra Chiini.{{sfn|Heath|1999|pp=4–5}}
[[Arabic language|Arabic]], introduced together with Islam during the 11th century, has mainly been the language of scholars and religion, comparable to [[Latin]] in [[Western Christianity]].<ref name=timeslibraries>{{Cite news |last=Forma |first=Aminatta |title=The Lost Libraries of Timbuktu |newspaper=The Sunday Times |location=London, UK |date=7 February 2009 |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article5675598.ece |accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref> Although [[Bambara language|Bambara]] is spoken by the most numerous ethnic group in Mali, the [[Bambara people]], it is mainly confined to the south of the country. With an improving infrastructure granting Timbuktu access to larger cities in Mali's South, use of Bambara was increasing in the city at least until Azawad independence.{{sfn|Heath|1999|pp=4–5}}
==Infrastructure== With no railroads in Mali except for the [[Dakar-Niger Railway]] up to [[Koulikoro]], access to Timbuktu is by road, boat or, since 1961, aircraft.<ref>{{citation |last=Rosberg |first=Carl Gustav |title=Political Parties and National Integration in Tropical Africa |publisher=University of California Press |year=1964 |location=Berkeley, CA |page=222 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JpNYxFmTjC4C&pg=PA222 }}</ref> With high water levels in the Niger from August to December, Compagnie Malienne de Navigation (COMANAV) passenger ferries operate a leg between Koulikoro and downstream [[Gao]] on a roughly weekly basis. Also requiring high water are ''pinasses'' (large motorized [[pirogues]]), either [[charter]]ed or public, that travel up and down the river.<ref name=lpafrica>{{Cite book |last=Pitcher |first=Gemma |title=Africa |publisher=Lonely Planet Guides |year=2007 |location=Melbourne |pages=403–418 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pES7tpurfx0C&dq=timbuktu+lonely+planet&source=gbs_navlinks_s }}</ref>
Both ferries and ''pinasses'' arrive at Korioumé, Timbuktu's port, which is linked to the city centre by an {{convert|18|km|mi|abbr=on}} paved road running through Kabara. In 2007, access to Timbuktu's traditional port, Kabara, was restored by a [[Libya]]n funded project that dredged the {{convert|3|km|0|abbr=on}} silted canal connecting Kabara to an arm of the Niger River. COMANAV ferries and ''pinassses'' are now able to reach the port when the river is in full flood.<ref name="retour"/><ref name=autogenerated1>{{citation | title= Lancement des travaux du Canal de Tombouctou : la mamelle nourricière redonne vie et espoir à la 'Cité mystérieuse' |date=14 August 2006 | url=http://www.afribone.com/spip.php?article4208 | publisher=Afribone }}</ref>
Timbuktu is poorly connected to the Malian road network with only dirt roads to the neighbouring towns. Although the Niger River can be crossed by ferry at Korioumé, the roads south of the river are no better. However, a new paved road is under construction between [[Niono]] and Timbuktu running to the north of the [[Inland Niger Delta]]. The {{convert|565|km|0|abbr=on}} road will pass through [[Nampala]], [[Léré, Tombouctou Region|Léré]], [[Niafunké]], [[Tonka, Tombouctou Region|Tonka]], [[Diré]] and [[Goundam]].<ref name=essor2010>{{citation |last=Coulibaly |first=Baye |title=Route Tombouctou-Goma Coura: un nouveau chantier titanesque est ouvert |publisher=L'Essor |url=http://www.essor.ml/actualite/article/kidal |date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref><ref name=essor2012>{{citation |last=Coulibaly |first=Baye |title=Route Tombouctou-Goma Coura: le chantier advance à grand pas |publisher=L'Essor |url=http://www.essor.ml/regions/article/route-tombouctou-goma-coura-le |date=19 January 2012 |accessdate=1 May 2012 }}</ref> The completed {{convert|81|km|0|abbr=on}} section between Niono and the small village of Goma Coura was financed by the [[Millennium Challenge Corporation]].<ref>{{citation | title=Niono-Goma Coura Road Inauguration | publisher=Embassy of the United States, Mali | url=http://mali.usembassy.gov/amb-speech-road-inaug.html | accessdate=19 March 2011 | date=7 February 2009 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514053419/http://mali.usembassy.gov/amb-speech-road-inaug.html | archivedate=14 May 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> This new section will service the Alatona irrigation system development of the [[Office du Niger]].<ref>{{citation |title=Mali Compact |publisher=Millennium Challenge Corporation |url=http://www.mcc.gov/documents/cn/cn-111706-mali-compactsigning.pdf |date=17 November 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325161914/http://www.mcc.gov/documents/cn/cn-111706-mali-compactsigning.pdf |archivedate=25 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The {{convert|484|km|0|abbr=on}} section between Goma Coura and Timbuktu is being financed by the [[European Development Fund]].<ref name=essor2010/>
[[Timbuktu Airport]] is served by both [[Air Mali (2005)|Air Mali]] and [[Mali Air Express]], hosting flights to and from Bamako, Gao and [[Mopti]].<ref name=lpafrica/> Its 6,923 ft (2,110 m) runway in a 07/25 [[Runway#Orientation and dimensions|runway orientation]] is both lighted and paved.<ref>{{citation | title = Pilot Information for Timbuktu Airport | publisher=Megginson Technologies | year = 2010 | url = http://www.ourairports.com/airports/GATB/pilot-info.html | accessdate =18 February 2011}}</ref>
==In popular culture== In the imagination of Europeans and North Americans, Timbuktu is a place that bears with it a sense of mystery: a 2006 survey of 150 young [[British people|Britons]] found 34% did not believe the town existed, while the other 66% considered it "a mythical place".<ref name=BBC_twin>{{citation | title = Search on for Timbuktu's twin | publisher =BBC News | date = 18 October 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6062360.stm | accessdate =22 November 2010}}</ref> This sense has been acknowledged in literature describing African history and African-European relations. Timbuktu is also often considered a far away place, in popular western culture.<ref name="Pelizzo"/>{{sfn|Saad|1983}}<ref name=Prescott>{{Cite book |last=Barrows |first=David Prescott |title=Berbers and Blacks: Impressions of Morocco, Timbuktu and the Western Sudan |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |location=Whitefish, Montana |year=1927 |page=10 }}</ref>
The origin of this mystification lies in the excitement brought to Europe by the legendary tales, especially those by [[Leo Africanus]]: Arabic sources focused mainly on more affluent cities in the Timbuktu region, such as [[Gao]] and [[Walata]].{{sfn|Insoll|2004}} In West Africa the city holds an image that has been compared to Europe's view on [[Athens]].{{sfn|Saad|1983}} As such, the picture of the city as the [[epitome]] of distance and mystery is a European one.<ref name="Pelizzo"/>
Down-to-earth-aspects in Africanus' descriptions were largely ignored and stories of great riches served as a [[Catalysis|catalyst]] for travellers to visit the inaccessible city – with prominent French explorer [[René Caillié]] characterising Timbuktu as "a mass of ill-looking [[Adobe|houses built of earth]]".{{sfn|Caillié|1830| p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=u7xjAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA49 49 Vol. 2]}} Now opened up, many travellers acknowledged the unfitting description of an "African [[El Dorado]]".<ref name=benjaminsen>{{Cite journal |last=Benjaminsen |first=Tor A |last2=Berge |first2=Gunnvor |title=Myths of Timbuktu: From African El Dorado to Desertification |journal=International Journal of Political Economy |volume=34 |issue=1 |pages=31–59 |publisher=M.E. Sharpe, Inc. |location=Armonk, NY |year=2004 |url=http://econpapers.repec.org/article/mesijpoec/v_3a34_3ay_3a2004_3ai_3a1_3ap_3a31-59.htm |accessdate=14 September 2010}}</ref> This development shifted the city's reputation – from being fabled because of its gold to fabled because of its location and mystery: Being used in this sense since at least 1863, English dictionaries now cite Timbuktu as a [[metaphor]] for any faraway place.<ref>{{cite web | title = Entry on 'Timbuktu'| work=Online Etymology Dictionary | publisher=Douglas Harper| year = 2002 | url = http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=timbuktu&searchmode=none| accessdate =17 September 2010 }}</ref>
In "Scales of Gold" (1991), the fourth book in [[Dorothy Dunnett|Dorothy Dunnett’s]] House of Niccolo series, key characters go to Africa in 1464-1467 searching for gold. They find in Timbuktu intellectual and spiritual wealth that transforms them.
In the original 1932 recording of the popular seaside song "[[The Sun Has Got His Hat On]]", the second verse contains the lines: "[The Sun's] been tanning niggers out in Timbuktu / Now he's coming back to do the same to you!"<ref>{{cite news |title=BBC Radio Devon DJ David Lowe loses job over racist word|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-devon-27360884|work=[[BBC News]] |date=2014-05-11}}</ref> Due to the controversial nature of the racial epithet "[[nigger]]", controversy has arisen when this song has been played<ref name ="song">{{cite news |title=ITV feels the heat over N-word song lyrics |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/jun/26/itv-n-word |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2012-06-26 |first=Mark |last=Sweney}}</ref> and various replacements, including "[[negroes]]"<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lbeWBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA289 Jonathan King, ''70 FFFY'', 2014, p.289]</ref> and "roasting [[peanut]]s"<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Dn7WAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT53 Stephen Fry, ''More Fool Me'', 2014]</ref> have been offered.
Similar uses of the city are found in movies, where it is used to indicate a place a person or good cannot be traced – in a Dutch [[Donald Duck]] comic subseries situated in Timbuktu, Donald Duck uses the city as a safe haven,<ref>[http://coa.inducks.org/comp2.php?code=&keyw=timboektoe&keywt=i&exactpg=&pg1=&pg2=&bro2=&bro3=&kind=0&rowsperpage=0&columnsperpage=0&hero=&xapp=&univ=&xa2=&creat=&creat2=&plot=&plot2=&writ=&writ2=&art=&art2=&ink=&ink2=&pub1=&pub2=∂=&ser=&xref=&mref=&xrefd=&repabb=&repabbc=al&imgmode=1&vdesc2=on&vdesc=en&vnl=on&sort1=autoDonaldDuck Timboektoe subseries (Dutch)] on the [http://coa.inducks.org/ C.O.A. Search Engine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051126084649/http://coa.inducks.org/ |date=26 November 2005 }} (I.N.D.U.C.K.S.). Retrieved d.d. 24 October 2009.</ref> and in the 1970 [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]] [[traditional animation|animated feature]] ''[[The Aristocats]]'', Edgar, the butler villain of the story, threatens Thomas O'Malley, Duchess, Marie, and Berlioz with being sent to Timbuktu only for Thomas O'Malley's friends to rescue them and send Edgar there instead. It is mistakenly noted to be in [[French Equatorial Africa]], instead of [[French West Africa]].<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065421/goofs Notes on ''The Aristocats''] at the [[Internet Movie Database]]. Retrieved 24 October 2009</ref>
[[Ali Farka Touré]] inverted the stereotype: "For some people, when you say 'Timbuktu' it is like the end of the world, but that is not true. I am from Timbuktu, and I can tell you that we are right at the heart of the world."<ref>{{cite AV media | people = [[Ali Farka Touré]] with [[Ry Cooder]] | title = [[Talking Timbuktu]] | medium = CD (insert) | publisher = World Circuit |year=1994}}</ref>
==Twin towns – sister cities== Timbuktu is a [[Twin towns and sister cities|sister city]] to the following cities:<ref>{{cite news | title = Timbuktu 'twins' make first visit | publisher=BBC News | date = 24 October 2007 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/mid_/7058884.stm | accessdate =24 May 2010}}</ref> *{{flagicon|GER}} [[Chemnitz]], Germany *{{flagicon|WAL}} [[Hay-on-Wye]], Wales, United Kingdom *{{flagicon|TUN}} [[Kairuan]], Tunisia *{{flagicon|MAR}} [[Marrakech]], Morocco *{{flagicon|FRA}} [[Saintes, Charente-Maritime|Saintes]], France *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Tempe, Arizona]], United States

==1800s==
===1890-1899=== * Although Australia's first officially recognised experimental broadcast was made in 1905 (see below), there are reliable reports in September 1897<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article54509107 |title=Public Teachers' Union |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |volume=LXII, |issue=15,869 |location=South Australia |date=22 September 1897 |accessdate=31 October 2017 |page=6 |via=National Library of Australia}} There are earlier reports but this is the clearest and most interesting.</ref> (just two years after [[Guglielmo Marconi]]'s original radio experiments) of demonstrations of wireless communication in Australia conducted by Professor [[William Henry Bragg]] of [[Adelaide University]]<ref>http://www.wia.org.au/members/history/research/documents/WIA%20MAIN%20T-%20LINE-Nov%202013%20EXTENDED.pdf</ref><ref>Bernard Harte, ''When Radio Was The Cat's Whiskers'', 2002, privately published Dural, NSW</ref> following experiments by Bragg, and at some stage in conjunction with G.W. Selby of Melbourne.<ref>Mimi Colligan, ''Golden Days of Radio'', Australia Post, 1991</ref>
==1900s==
===1900-1909===
*1901: The six states [[Federation of Australia|federate]] into the Commonwealth of Australia. [[Section 51(v) of the Australian Constitution]] gives the [[Government of Australia|federal government]] power over "postal, telegraphic, telephonic, and other like services".<ref>[[Australian Senate]], 2003. [http://www.aph.gov.au/senate/general/constitution/par5cha1.htm Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act: Chapter I. The Parliament: Part V - Powers of the Parliament.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111014193759/http://www.aph.gov.au/senate/general/constitution/par5cha1.htm |date=2011-10-14 }} Retrieved 2011-03-05.</ref> *1905: **''Wireless Telegraphy Act (1905)''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Series/C2004A07672|title=Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905|publisher=ComLaw|accessdate=2012-10-01}}</ref> placed broadcasting in the control of the Australian Government. This has remained in place ever since.<ref name="Langdon">[http://www.acmi.net.au/AIC/RADIO_HIST_AUS.html Langdon, Jeff (1995)]</ref> **Italian [[Guglielmo Marconi]]’s company builds [[Australia]]'s first two-way wireless telegraphy station at [[Queenscliff, Victoria]].<ref name = "Langdon"/> *1906: first official transmission between Queenscliff and [[Devonport, Tasmania]].<ref>R R Walker, ''The Magic Spark'', 1973, Hawthorn Press Melbourne.</ref>
===1910-1919=== *1910: The Maritime Wireless Co. Ltd formed by [[Edward Hope Kirkby]], his workers and Father Archibald Shaw<ref>Correspondence from Father Guis Archives of the Missionaries of the Sacred Heart - Missionarii Sacratissimi Cordis Iesu (MSC) Archives Sacred Heart Monastery, 1 Roma Avenue, Kensington 2033 - 1911</ref> *1910: March 11th, The [[Wireless Institute of Australia]] is formed during a meeting held at the [[Australia Hotel]] in Martin Place, Sydney.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wia.org.au/joinwia/wia/about/|title=Information about the WIA|accessdate=2017-08-28}}</ref> *1911: The Maritime Wireless Co. Ltd sold to The Maritime Wireless Company (Shaw System) Limited<ref>Articles of Association of said company Archives of the Missionaries of the Sacred Heart - Missionarii Sacratissimi Cordis Iesu (MSC) Archives Sacred Heart Monastery, 1 Roma Avenue, Kensington 2033 - 1911</ref> *1911: Australian Government employs their own wireless expert to build the coastal wireless service after interests representing [[Telefunken]] didn't perform to the governments satisfaction on the first 2 at Sydney and Perth - Graeme Balsillie <ref>National Archives of Australia, Melbourne Office: John Graeme Balsillie - Records (1910 - 1920) Information and records in Postmaster-General, correspondence files c1910-20 [MP 341/1].MP 341/1</ref> *1911: Balsillie contracts the Maritime Wireless Company (Shaw System) Limited to manufacture all the apparatus for the remaining 17 wireless including the generators and motors<ref>copy of the contract Archives of the Missionaries of the Sacred Heart - Missionarii Sacratissimi Cordis Iesu (MSC) Archives Sacred Heart Monastery, 1 Roma Avenue, Kensington 2033 - 1911</ref> *1912: The first Coastal wireless station opened in Melbourne *1911: The first long range (520 km) coastal radio station was established in Sydney.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.airwaysmuseum.com/Coastal%20Radio%20Stations.htm|title=The Role of Coastal Radio Stations in the Early Days of Communications With Aircraft|author=Roger Meyer|accessdate=2012-09-30}}</ref> *1912: **The [[Applecross Wireless Station]] long range station was established in Western Australia. **Shorter range stations were established in Melbourne, Hobart, Brisbane and Adelaide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.st.net.au/~dunn/sigint/crs.htm|title=Coastal Radio Service in Australia during WWII|publisher=Peter Dunn's "Australia @ War"|accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref> *1913: Marconi and its main competitor Telefunken amalgamated to form [[Amalgamated Wireless Australasia Limited]] (AWA).<ref name = "Langdon"/> *1919: The first radio "broadcast" in Australia was organised by [[Ernest Fisk|Ernest Thomas Fisk]] of AWA on 19 August 1919. He arranged for the National Anthem to be broadcast from one building to another at the end of a lecture he'd given on the new medium to the [[Royal Society of New South Wales]].<ref name = "Langdon"/>
===1920-1929=== *1921: **Amateur radio broadcasters commenced transition. The first radio licence in Australia was granted to Charles Maclurcan for station [[2CM - an Australian pioneer broadcaster|2CM]], which broadcast from the Wentworth Hotel in Sydney, an establishment owned by the Maclurcan family. Broadcasts consisted of classical music concerts on air on Sunday nights. *1922: ** December, "The Regulations: radio laws for the amateur" was issued by the Australian Government. This resulted in Australia's first broadcast licence (2CM in Sydney) being issued to Charles MacLurcan in December 1922. ref "Australian Radio History". *1923: **Following intensive lobbying for the introduction of radio broadcasting, the Government, in May 1923, calls a conference of the main players in the radio manufacturing industry. This led to the [[sealed set]] regulations where stations could be licensed to broadcast and then sell sets to "listeners-in". The receiving device would be set to receive only that station.<ref name = "Langdon"/> **[[702 ABC Sydney|2SB]] (from 1924, 2BL) in [[Sydney]] is the second official station to be licensed. It commenced service on 23 November 1923. Sydney's first official station, [[Radio National|2FC]] with Licence No.1 commenced service on 9 January 1924.<ref>''Australian Radio History'', Bruce Carty, Sydney, 2011</ref> *1924: **3AR and 3LO went to air on 26 January and 13 October 1924 in [[Melbourne]].<ref name = "Langdon"/> **The Government introduces a two-tiered licence system in July 1924. In the first half of 1924, only 1400 people took out sealed set licences. It was quite easy for listeners to avoid the licence fee by building their own sets or modifying one they had bought to receive more than one station. The radio industry successfully lobbied the Government to introduce a two-tiered system, the "A" licenses to be financed by listeners' licence fees imposed and collected by the Government, and "B" class licenses to be offered to anyone else who wanted to have a go. The B stations would have to generate their own revenue through advertising. A class stations could also advertise but few did. This system was an amalgam of the British system where the non-commercial BBC had a government-imposed monopoly and the USA where the free market was the driving force. The "A" class stations were the original sealed set stations plus one in each other capital city - 2BL, 2FC, 3AR, 3LO, 7ZL, 5CL, 6WF. By years end, 40,000 licences have been issued.<ref name = "Langdon"/> At this time, there was also talk of the introduction "C" class stations which would exclusively advertise the products of the station owners(s). This concept was abandoned in 1931, but the [[Postmaster-General's Department]] was already in talks with the Akron Broadcasting Co. Pty. Ltd in Melbourne, and, so, in lieu of a "C" class license Akron was given a 'B" Class license with some severe restricting conditions (see [[3AK]]). **The first "B" class station on air was 2BE in November 1924.<ref name = "Langdon"/> **[[South Australia]]’s first radio station 5CL (A class) went to air on 20 November.<ref name = "Langdon"/> *1925: **The oldest surviving "B" class (commercial) station is [[2UE]], which went on air on [[Australia Day]] 1925 as [[2UE|2EU]].<ref name = "Langdon"/> The reputed reason for the change of callsign is that EU sounded like "''Hey, You''". **[[3UZ]] Melbourne begins broadcasting **South Australia’s first commercial radio station [[5DN]] goes to air 24 February.<ref name = "Langdon"/> **Number of licences issued reaches 80,000.<ref name = "Langdon"/> *1926: The British Government nationalises radio by buying out the [[British Broadcasting Company]] and forming the [[British Broadcasting Corporation]]. The Australian Government held a [[Royal Commission]] into Wireless but didn't immediately follow the British lead. It did encourage the "A" class stations to amalgamate in order to maximise efficiencies and maintain standards.<ref name = "Langdon"/> *1927: **AWA conducts a series of transmissions to Britain. These regular broadcasts were heralded by a [[kookaburra]]'s laugh - a practice that's still used by Radio Australia today, nicknamed "Jacko".<ref name = "Langdon"/> **[[3TTT|3DB]] Melbourne commences broadcasting *1929: **2BE closes due to financial collapse.<ref name = "Langdon"/> **The Government nationalises the transmission facilities and contracts the provision of programming to the Australian Broadcasting Company (now Australian Broadcasting Corporation), a consortium of entertainment interests.<ref name = "Langdon"/>
===1930-1939===
*1932: **The [[Australian Broadcasting Company]] is nationalised by the ''Australian Broadcasting Commission Act (1932).'' This finalised the two-tier system with the national broadcaster, the newly created [[Australian Broadcasting Commission]], having 12 stations, and the commercial sector, with 43 stations. The ABC was funded by listeners’ licence fees until the 1970s, when Federal Government appropriation became the primary source of funding. Initial plans to permit advertising on the ABC were dropped from the final bill presented to the parliament.<ref name = "Langdon"/> **On 29 June 1932, [[2WG]] in [[Wagga Wagga, New South Wales]] goes on the air on a purpose built 2000 watt transmitter.<ref>{{cite web |title = Radio Station 2WG |url = http://www.wagga.nsw.gov.au/www/html/1078-radio-station-2wg.asp |publisher = Wagga Wagga City Council |accessdate = 2008-03-24 }}</ref> **At 8.00pm on 1 July 1932, the Prime Minister, [[Joseph Lyons]], inaugurates the ABC. It then controlled 12 stations – [[2FC]] and [[2BL (AM)|2BL]] in Sydney, 3AR and [[3LO]] in Melbourne, 4QG in [[Brisbane]], [[5CL]] in [[Adelaide]], [[6WF]] in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], 7ZL in [[Hobart]] and the relay stations [[1233 ABC Newcastle|2NC]] in [[Newcastle, New South Wales]], [[2CO]] at [[Corowa, New South Wales]], [[4RK]] in [[Rockhampton, Queensland]] and [[5CK]] at [[Crystal Brook, South Australia]].<ref name = "ABCHistory">[http://www.abc.net.au/radio/celebrate100/history.htm History of ABC Radio]</ref> *1935: **The Sydney studios of the ABC installs a disc recorder, enabling the recording of programs to occur for the first time.<ref name = "ABCHistory"/> **Many Australian radio stations change frequencies on 1 Sep 1935 to accord Australian 10 kHz frequency raster and to resolve interference problems.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article81711709 |title=New and Old Wavelengths |newspaper=[[Singleton Argus]] |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=2 September 1935 |accessdate=30 October 2017 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> *1936: In March, the [[Bass Strait]] cable links [[Tasmania]] to mainland Australia and permits the ABC to relay national broadcasts to Hobart for the first time.<ref name = "ABCHistory"/> *1939: [[Radio Australia]] was formally incorporated as part of the ABC.<ref name = "ABCHistory"/>
===1940-1949===
*1945: **Hector Crawford Productions, later called [[Crawford Productions]], was founded by [[Hector Crawford]] and his sister [[Dorothy Crawford]]. They would also run the Crawford School of Broadcasting, which taught radio actors such as [[Noel Ferrier]] skills for a radio broadcasting career. Crawford Productions as one of the few companies that successfully made a transition from radio to television.<ref name="York1999">{{cite book|author=Barry York|title=Speaking of Us: Voices from Twentieth-century Australia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XgUAvuQBp-wC&pg=PA71|date=1 January 1999|publisher=National Library Australia|isbn=978-0-642-10715-2|pages=71–}}</ref> *1948: **Experimental FM broadcasts commence<ref name = "Langdon"/> **The regulatory body, the Australian Broadcasting Control Board, is created<ref name = "Langdon"/>
===1950-1959===
*1957: A Government inquiry into FM radio heralds little interest<ref name = "Langdon"/> *1958: [[Top 40]] format is adopted by Australian commercial radio
===1960-1969===
*1961: The Government authorises the use of the international VHF FM band for television.<ref name = "Langdon"/> *1967: [[Talk radio|Talkback radio]] began in early 1967 on 6PR in Perth it was later introduced on [[2SM]] in Sydney and [[3AW]] in Melbourne.<ref name = "Milesago">[http://www.milesago.com/Radio/radiochron.htm Australasian radio: A Chronology of the first 60 years (2004)]</ref> *1968: [[3AK]] Melbourne expands to 24-hour transmission
===1970-1979===
*1970: **[[TUNE! FM]] launches as Australia's first university radio station. *1972: **The Labor government's Media Minister Doug McClelland abolishes radio and TV licence fees, making the ABC funded directly from the federal budget<ref name = "Milesago"/> **[[5UV]] in Adelaide becomes the first public radio station on air in Australia<ref name = "Milesago"/> *1974: **The McLean Inquiry into FM rejects the Broadcasting Control Board's views on FM radio and recommends that the VHF FM band be opened to FM radio stations, that a community radio sector be established, and that the ABC have an FM network<ref name = "Milesago"/> **[[2MBS]] Sydney commences broadcasting as the first full-time FM station in Australia, playing classical music 24 hours a day. *1975: **[[2JJJ|2JJ]] (Double Jay) commences transmission on the AM band in Sydney. Double Jay is the first non-commercial 24-hour rock station in Australia<ref name = "Milesago"/> **3MBS-FM Melbourne commences broadcasting classical music 24 hours a day<ref name = "Milesago"/> **Multi-cultural radio is launched with the formation of [[SBS Radio|2EA]] Sydney and [[SBS Radio|3EA]] Melbourne **Public access station [[3ZZ]] is established in Melbourne<ref name = "Milesago"/> **Twelve Australian community radio stations are licensed as an interim move by the federal media minister, Dr Moss Cass. Because the licences may have been technically illegal under the Act, they are dubbed Cass's "Dirty Dozen"<ref name = "Milesago"/> ** Brisbane's [[4ZZZ]] is established, the first community FM broadcaster in Australia *1976: **[[ABC Classic FM|ABC FM]] begins broadcasting **[[3MP]] begins broadcasting, the first new commercial radio licence in Melbourne since 1935 * 1977: ** 6UVS begins broadcasting from the campus of UWA, Perth. (6UVS later becomes [[6RTR (FM)|6RTR]]) *1978: **All AM radio station frequencies are changed from 10 kHz to 9 kHz spacing under the [[Geneva Frequency Plan of 1975]] on 23 November. **[[2WS]] Sydney begins broadcasting *1979 **PBS FM starts regular broadcasts on 21 December from the Prince of Wales Hotel studio.<ref name=PBSFM>http://www.pbsfm.org.au/history</ref>
===1980-1989===
*1980: **The first commercial FM radio stations are launched: [[3EON]] and [[3FOX]] in Melbourne, [[2MMM]] and [[2DAY]] Sydney, [[4MMM]] Brisbane, [[5SSA]] Adelaide, [[6NOW|96FM]] Perth *1982: **[[7RPH]] in Hobart becomes the first ''Radio for the Print Handicapped'' broadcast service. Other stations soon follow in [[3RPH|Melbourne]], [[2RPH|Sydney]], [[4RPH|Brisbane]], [[Radio 1RPH|Canberra]], [[5RPH|Adelaide]] and [[6RPH|Perth]]. *1984: **[[AM Stereo|Stereo AM]] radio transmission is launched *1986: **[[2UE]] Sydney and [[3AK]] Melbourne launch the experimental CBC Radio Network, a networked talk-back format *1988: **Commercial FM radio is launched in [[Canberra]] *1989: **Commercial FM radio launches on the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]] **Sydney's [[2JJJ|Triple J]] begins expansion to other capital cities
===1990-1999===
*1990: **[[3KZ]] Melbourne converts from AM to FM. Other stations to convert include [[3TT]] Melbourne, [[4BK]] Brisbane, [[6PM]] and [[6KY]] Perth, [[5KA]] and [[5DN]] Adelaide. **May 19, 1990, Australia's first S39 supplementary FM Station goes to air in regional Australia as 2VM Moree Launch 2NOW (NOW FM) on 98.3 From Mt Dowe in North West NSW. **Commercial FM commences in [[Hobart]] **[[3AK]] becomes Australia's first [[Italian-language]] commercial radio station *1991: **Melbourne radio station [[3XY]] signs off after 56 years of broadcasting *1992: **[[8DN]] [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] has its licence revoked for breaching the ownership conditions of the Broadcasting Act *1994: **[[2UW]] and [[2WS]] Sydney convert to FM **[[2WZD]] begins broadcasting in Wagga Wagga as FM93. **[[ABC NewsRadio|ABC Newsradio]] is launched *1998: **NetFM broadcasts Australia's first Internet radio transmission. **NetFM commence full commercial broadcasting in Sydney on 13 November.
==2000s==
===2000-2009===
*2000: Triple J [[New England (New South Wales)|New England]] was first broadcast *2001: DMG Launches the Nova brand with Sydney's [[Nova 969]] first hitting the airwaves. *2002: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation commences a digital radio service called [[ABC DiG|DiG]] in November. *2004: [[3AK]] Melbourne becomes an all-sports format as [[SEN 1116|SEN]] *2005: **Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) is formed on 1 July 2005 by the merger of the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) and the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) *2006: Melbourne radio stations [[3AW]] and [[3EE|Magic]] swap frequencies on the AM band *2009: [[Digital radio in Australia|Digital radio]] officially launches in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth.
===2010-present=== *2011 **[http://www.aussie.fm Aussie.fm] launches its free online radio portal dedicated to Australian radio. *2014 **[[Macquarie Radio Network]] and [[Fairfax Media#Radio|Fairfax Radio Network]] merger is announced in December. **Fairfax Radio Network sells [[6NOW|96FM]] Perth to [[Australian Radio Network]] ahead of Macquarie merger. *2015 **Macquarie Radio Network and Fairfax Radio Network merger is approved, with [[2CH]] Sydney and [[4LM]] Mount Isa to be sold.
==See also==
*[[Timeline of radio]] *[[History of broadcasting]]
==Notes==

== References == *[http://www.abc.net.au/radio/celebrate100/history.htm ''History of ABC Radio''] *[http://www.milesago.com/Radio/radiochron.htm ''Australasian radio: A Chronology of the first 60 years'' (2004)] *[http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/13071/20040303-0000/www.acmi.net.au/AIC/RADIO_HIST_AUS.html Langdon, Jeff (1995) ''The History of Radio in Australia: Excerpts from a Lecture given by Dr Jeff Langdon in 1995] *Johnson, Lesley. "Radio and everyday life The early years of broadcasting in Australia, 1922-1945." Media, Culture & Society 3.2 (1981): 167-178. * Browne, Donald R. "Aboriginal Radio in Australia: From Dreamtime to Prime Time?." Journal of Communication 40.1 (1990): 111-121.
== External links == *[http://www.australianotr.com.au The Home of the Old Time Radio Shows Group (Australia)] * Visit the [[National Film and Sound Archive]] of Australia's [https://web.archive.org/web/20120325121741/http://nfsa.gov.au/collection/sound/women-early-radio/ Women in Early Radio] collection for more information about the history of women in radio in Australia, including [[Queenie Ashton]], [[Ethel Lang (actress)|Ethel Lang]], [[Amber Mae Cecil]] and [[Grace Gibson]]. *[http://www.aussie.fm Aussie.fm - Listen to Australian radio online]
